docTitle.titlePart:
Effect of Amino Acid Substitution by Site-directed Mutagenesis on
the Carbohydrate Recognition and Stability of Human 14-kDa
0-Galactoside-binding Lectin*

byline.affiliation: From the Department of Biological Chemistry, Facu1t.y of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Teikyo University,

front.div:
The roles of selected amino acid residues of human
14-kDa B-galactoside-binding lectin were studied by
site-directed mutagenesis. Ten mutant lectin proteins
were produced, in each of which one of the residues
regarded as possibly related to the stability of the lectin
(6 cysteine residues) or one of those highly conserved
in the vertebrate 8-galactoside-binding lectin family
(Asn4', Trp68, Glu'l, and Arg73), was substituted. All
the mutant lectins in which one of the cysteine residues
had been substituted with serine (C2S, C16S, C42S,
C60S, C88S, and C130S) proved to have sugar binding
ability comparable with that of the wild-type lectin. In
addition, one of the mutants in which Cys2 was substi-
tuted (C2S) was found to have become considerably
more stable under non-reducing conditions. It retained
asialofetuin binding activity for over a week in the
absence of 8-mercaptoethanol, while the wild-type lec-
tin lost it within a day. This suggests that oxidation of
Cys2 could be a key process in the inactivation of
human 14-kDa lectin. Substitution of highly conserv-
ative Trp" to tyrosine (W68Y) slightly reduced lactose
binding ability, but the mutant was still adsorbed
strongly on asialofetuin-agarose. Other mutant lectins
in which conservative hydrophilic amino acids were
substituted (N46D, E71Q, and R73H) failed to bind to
the asialofetuin agarose, with no sign of retardation.
Thus, conservative hydrophilic residues proved to be
more important in carbohydrate recognition than the
cysteine and tryptophan residues, contrary
to the
widely accepted concept that these latter residues are
essential.

Vertebrate P-galactoside-binding lectins form a protein
family (1) and have characteristics distinct from those of
animal lectins belonging to another family, that is the Ca2+-
dependent lectin family (2). They have been found only in
vertebrates, require no metal ion for sugar binding, and have
some typical characteristics of intracellular proteins, that is
lack of a representative hydrophobic signal sequence in the
nascent protein, lack of a carbohydrate chain, and the exist-
ence of free cysteine residues not involved in disulfide bond
